title.narrative: Support to RCN Justice et Democratie for local mediators (ABUNZI)

description.narrative: Det övergripande målet är att se till att jordreform i Rwanda är en möjlighet för alla att förbättra sin sociala och ekonomiska situation och upprätthålla likabehandling av kvinnor och män på landsbygden genom att förbättra hanteringen av marktvister i 15 distrikt med särskild betoning på kvinnors rättigheter och intressen i landfrågor. Målgrupperna är främst Abunzi kommittéer och opinionsbildare.

The overall objective is to ensure that the land reform in Rwanda is an opportunity for everyone to improve their socio-economic situation and uphold the equal treatment of women and men in rural areas by improving management of land conflicts in 15 districts with particulat attention to safeguarding women's rights and interests in land.The project targets Abunzi committees and opinion leaders.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The Project that lasted from 1st October 2012 until September 2015 with a total budget of SEK 30,872,502, implemented in 15 districts of Rwanda achieved two main outcomes.
First, the capacities of Mediation (Abunzi) committees of the 15 districts (Musanze, Gakenke, Rulindo (North); Muhanga, Nyanza, Nyamagabe Nyaruguru (South); Rusizi, Nyamasheke, Rubavu (West), Gatsibo, Kirehe, Bugesera and Rwamagana (East) and Gasabo in Kigali was strengthened through training, consultation workshops, distribution of needed Equipments and Tools, monitoring and couching and publication of studies. A total of 2491 members of Abunzi commiittees at all levels, local authorities and CSOs benefited from capacity building activities. As a result, the abunzi committees became more able to offer adequate solutions to people involved in land conflicts while enforcing women's land rights. Some tangile results include: Abunzi (mediators) and Executive Secretaries (all local levels) have increased their knowledge; Summons are now usually delivered on time; attempts at Mediation have significantly increased; Copies of the minutes are delivered on time more frequently; and requests for Money by Abunzi have significantly reduced.
Secondly, rural population (men and women) and the authorities involved in land issues recognized and committed to better promote women’s land rights. This was achieved theough trainings, dissemination of relevant Laws, Community discussions and dialogues at local and national levels. A total of 5,500,000 mostly rural women and men benefited from these activities by claiming their land rights through mediation. In terms of tangible results, Knowledge of women’s rights has increased; More women are bringing land cases to the Abunzi; and Local authorities recognized the barriers to justice faced by women.
In terms of the Impact of the ILPRC project, RCN has collected many testimonies of impacts (especially the protection and promotion of women's land interests) and a selection were documented in the final completion report RCN submitted to the embassy in 2016.
It is worth to note that the sustainability of the Project activities is assured through transfer of knowledge to Abunzi (mediators), Ministry of Justice Lawyers at districts-Maisons d'access a la Justice (MAJ), Executive Secretaries at different levels, community mobelisers (VAFs) from CSOs and Village Chiefs. Sustainability has also been ensured through distribution of sensitization tools (e.g copies of laws, training manuals, mini guide, image toolboxes; leaflets and posters on 1999 succession law and 2005 land law; posters on expropriation rules, etc). In addition, Institutionalization of standard forms by Ministry of Justice (eg summons copies of minutes, etc.) has been done. Advocacy for adequate budget support has aslo been ensured throught the Project.
Partners to RCN in the achievement of both results have been Ministry of Justice, local NGOs ARAMA, IMBARAGA, AVEGA AGAHOZO and RRP+; National Women's Council and local authorities (districts, sectors, cells and villages) have been instrumental.
?
?
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
